title: Gastric Adenocarcinoma
diagnosis_topic: Gastric Cancer Requiring Staging and Surgical Management
setup_script: “A 65-year-old man with a history of smoking presents to your clinic with progressive weight loss, early satiety, and vague epigastric discomfort. His stool tested positive for occult blood. On exam, he appears thin but stable. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 130/70 mmHg, HR 90 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 37 °C.
An ulcerated mass is seen in the gastric antrum. Biopsies reveal intestinal-type adenocarcinoma.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders staging with CT and endoscopic ultrasound
dynamic_flow.reply: CT shows thickened gastric wall without distant metastasis. EUS demonstrates T2N1 lesion with 2 involved regional nodes.
Mild anemia (Hgb 9.5 g/dL) and hypoalbuminemia are noted.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses plan with multidisciplinary team
dynamic_flow.reply: Recommendation is for neoadjuvant chemotherapy (FLOT) followed by subtotal gastrectomy with D2 lymphadenectomy.
Tumor progresses, resulting in unresectable disease or metastasis.
Subtotal gastrectomy with 5 cm margins; reconstruction with Billroth II or Roux-en-Y.
Noted to improve survival in stage II/III disease; risks include neutropenia and mucositis.
Requires gastric resection with en bloc D2 nodal dissection. Anastomosis performed in standard fashion.
Early jejunal feeding, monitor for anastomotic leak, deficiencies (B12, iron), and dumping syndrome.
CT and endoscopy every 6 months for 2 years, then annually.
Smoking cessation, nutritional counseling, psychosocial support offered.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to address recurrence surveillance
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient later presents with weight loss and liver lesions. Biopsy confirms metastasis.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of gastric cancer via endoscopy and biopsy
Staging with CT and endoscopic ultrasound
Use of neoadjuvant chemotherapy and surgical resection with adequate lymphadenectomy
